content.title: Wolff-Parkinson-White Syndrome
content.summary: Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome is a pre-excitation syndrome caused by an accessory pathway (bundle of Kent) that bypasses the AV node, creating the characteristic delta wave on ECG. Patients may develop atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia (AVRT) or, dangerously, rapidly conducted atrial fibrillation that can degenerate into ventricular fibrillation. Catheter ablation is curative.
key_points: ECG triad: short PR (<120ms), delta wave, wide QRS
Accessory pathway conducts faster than AV node (ventricular pre-excitation)
Orthodromic AVRT: narrow QRS, antegrade through AV node
Antidromic AVRT: wide QRS, antegrade through accessory pathway
AF with WPW: rapid irregular wide-complex tachycardia; potentially fatal
Avoid AV nodal blockers (adenosine, verapamil, digoxin) in pre-excited AF
content.statement: Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome is a pre-excitation condition with an accessory pathway causing delta waves on ECG and predisposing to AVRT and rapidly conducted atrial fibrillation, requiring catheter ablation for definitive treatment.

explanation.intuition: The heart normally has one electrical 'bridge' between atria and ventricles (AV node), which slows conduction for proper timing. In WPW, there's a second 'bridge' (accessory pathway) that conducts faster, causing early ventricular activation (pre-excitation) seen as the delta wave.
explanation.key_insight: The danger of WPW is atrial fibrillation: the accessory pathway can conduct AF at rates >300 bpm, overwhelming the ventricles and triggering VF. That's why AV nodal blockers (which normally help in AF) are CONTRAINDICATED - they remove competition, allowing even faster accessory pathway conduction.
explanation.technical_details: The accessory pathway (bundle of Kent) lacks decremental conduction properties of the AV node. Orthodromic AVRT uses antegrade AV node conduction and retrograde accessory pathway; antidromic uses the reverse. Pre-excited AF shows irregular wide-complex rhythm with varying QRS morphology.

definitions_glossary.WPW_syndrome: Pre-excitation syndrome with accessory pathway and symptomatic tachyarrhythmias
definitions_glossary.WPW_pattern: ECG findings of pre-excitation without documented arrhythmias
definitions_glossary.delta_wave: Slurred initial upstroke of QRS from early ventricular activation
definitions_glossary.pre_excitation: Ventricular activation earlier than expected via accessory pathway
definitions_glossary.accessory_pathway: Bundle of Kent; anomalous connection between atrium and ventricle
definitions_glossary.orthodromic_AVRT: Reentry using AV node antegrade, accessory pathway retrograde; narrow QRS
definitions_glossary.antidromic_AVRT: Reentry using accessory pathway antegrade, AV node retrograde; wide QRS
definitions_glossary.pre_excited_AF: AF conducting rapidly over accessory pathway; irregular wide-complex tachycardia
definitions_glossary.short_PR_interval: PR <120ms from rapid accessory pathway conduction
definitions_glossary.catheter_ablation: Radiofrequency or cryoablation of accessory pathway; curative
definitions_glossary.concealed_accessory_pathway: Pathway conducts only retrograde; no delta wave in sinus rhythm
definitions_glossary.Ebstein_anomaly: Congenital heart defect associated with WPW (right-sided pathways)

pathophysiology.mechanism: Accessory pathway allows bypass of normal AV nodal delay

accessory_pathway.anatomy: Muscular bridge crossing AV groove (most commonly left free wall)
accessory_pathway.conduction: Faster than AV node; no decremental properties
accessory_pathway.result: Ventricular pre-excitation causing delta wave and short PR

orthodromic_AVRT.circuit: Antegrade through AV node, retrograde through accessory pathway
orthodromic_AVRT.ECG: Narrow QRS SVT with retrograde P waves in ST segment

antidromic_AVRT.circuit: Antegrade through accessory pathway, retrograde through AV node

pre_excited_AF.danger: Rapid conduction over accessory pathway (RR <250ms) can trigger VF
pre_excited_AF.ECG: Irregular wide-complex tachycardia with varying QRS morphology

pathway_localization.algorithms: Multiple algorithms (Arruda, Milstein) for precise localization

narrow_complex_AVRT.first_line: Vagal maneuvers, then adenosine 6→12→12mg IV push

pre_excited_AF_wide_complex.reason: Block AV node, enhance accessory pathway conduction → VF

catheter_ablation.procedure: EP study to map pathway, radiofrequency or cryoablation
catheter_ablation.risks: Recurrence 2-5%, AV block risk depends on pathway location

asymptomatic_WPW_pattern.risk_assessment: EP study to assess pathway properties (optional in low-risk)

definition.@value: A pre-excitation syndrome caused by an accessory atrioventricular pathway creating characteristic delta waves and predisposing to reentrant tachyarrhythmias

scopeNote.@value: Covers ECG diagnosis, arrhythmia mechanisms, acute management, and catheter ablation

learning_objectives: Identify the ECG triad of WPW: short PR, delta wave, wide QRS
Recognize the danger of pre-excited AF and avoid AV nodal blockers
Select appropriate acute management based on arrhythmia type
clinical_pearls: Irregular wide-complex tachycardia + WPW history = pre-excited AF until proven otherwise
NEVER give adenosine, verapamil, or digoxin in pre-excited AF → may cause VF
Procainamide is the drug of choice for pre-excited AF
Ablation is >95% curative and first-line for symptomatic WPW
WPW can cause pseudo-infarction pattern (delta waves mimic Q waves)
common_misconceptions: All wide-complex tachycardia is VT - antidromic AVRT is wide but supraventricular
Adenosine is safe for all SVT - contraindicated in pre-excited AF
Delta wave means symptomatic WPW - many are asymptomatic (WPW pattern only)
